quote: Tarkalean tea again, Doctor?
Yes, and I believe you're drinking    Rokassa juice, aren't you, Garak --
How did you know?
The odor is unmistakable.
So it is.  Rokassa juice soothes my    nerves.  I had a very demanding    customer today.  A Bajoran engineer    who comes into the shop constantly,    just to plague me...
I've always wondered about that...    about who your steady customers are...    I can't imagine Bajorans frequenting    a shop run by a Cardassian...
I like to think my expertise and    willingness to serve overcome any    general resentment my clientele may    have.
Ahhh.  Perhaps your expertise and    willingness to serve go so far as to    establish a certain... trust...    between you and your customers...
Trust is very important...
And once they trust you, they're    much more open with you... they...    tell you things...
Really, Doctor... must we play this    game so often?  I'm no more a "spy"    than you are a... a...
...Doctor.
I'm afraid you really do let your    imagination run away with you.  What    else can I say to convince you that    I'm just --
(finishing Garak's     sentence)   -- plain and simple Garak?
Precisely.
Now, there's something you don't see    every day...
There's a table.  Please, sit down    and I'll get all of us some    refreshment.
That was odd... do you know him?
On the contrary... I've never set    eyes on him before.
I hope I'm not intruding, but I    couldn't help noticing...
... what a handsome young man you    have here...
Stop it -- stop it!
Sorry I'm late --
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: The damnedest thing just happened...    Garak the tailor was attacked...
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: Attacked where?
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: At the Replimat.  He was bitten on    the hand...
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: Another unsatisfied customer?
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: He always cuts the pants too long...
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: No, it was a boy... a Cardassian    boy...
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: I wasn't aware we had any Cardassian    children on the station...
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: We don't...
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: He just arrived.  On the Bajoran    transport.  With an adult Bajoran    who says he's his father...
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: The boy was probably one of the    orphans left behind after the    Cardassians pulled out...    (she's reading     something on her     console, as she     presses panels... )   We had no choice but to take care of    them...       You have an incoming subspace    transmission... from Cardassia,    Commander...    (reading, looking up     to Sisko)   It's Gul Dukat.
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: In my office.
scene: 16   INT. OPS - ON THE TURBOLIFT RISING

quote: Commander... it's been brought to my    attention that the sole Cardassian    living on your station has been    assaulted...
I'm surprised how quickly the news    reached you, Dukat.  I only heard    about it myself a minute ago...
Is it true he was -- attacked -- by    a Cardassian boy brought to the    station by a Bajoran?
A Cardassian boy appears to have    been involved, yes.
It is exactly as I feared.     Exactly as I've been warning my    colleagues...
Warning them?

The Cardassian war orphans,    Commander... abandoned when we left    Bajor... it's a disgrace.  Obviously,    these children are being raised to    hate their own kind... this incident    is the proof...
You're assuming an awful lot from    this one incident...
Am I?  Then why would this boy assault    poor Garak?  An amiable fellow, if    there ever was one...
If you'd like, I'll try to find out.

That would be most appreciated.  I    need to know more about this boy,    Commander... so I can use his story    as ammunition in my fight to bring    these orphans back to their    homeland...       This is a tragedy all of us on    Cardassia must address...
We didn't come here to cause    trouble...
Has this Garak filed a complaint?
No... but Cardassian officials have    asked us to look into the incident...
I wish they'd been more concerned    when they left this boy and dozens    like him to fend for themselves...
How did you come to adopt him?
My wife and I felt that Rugal    shouldn't suffer for crimes committed    by others...
Any idea why he'd attack another    Cardassian?
That Cardassian should have minded    his own business.
Garak was only being friendly.  The    boy seemed terrified of him on sight.
The Cardassians are suggesting the    Bajorans are raising these orphans    to hate their own people.

(almost smiles, with     irony)   To hate Cardassians.  Well, that    wouldn't be too hard, would it.     We've told him the truth,    Commander.  The truth.  What    Cardassia did to Bajor.  He needed    to know.  I make no apologies for    that...       To us... he isn't even one of...    them... anymore.  He isn't Cardassian,    he's Bajoran.  And we love him as if    he were our own flesh and blood.
Dabo!  Dabo!  Dabo!
There's nothing quite so depressing    as a winning streak that won't stop    streaking.
It would appear you have the game    all figured out.
Dabo is a passion of mine.       I remember you.  You're Doctor...
Bashir.
Bashir, yes.  How's the Cardassian?     Still has all his fingers, I hope...
Yes.  Luckily there were no broken    bones.       I've never seen a boy take a bite    out of a man's hand like that...
He's a strange child, Rugal.
Do you know the family well?
Dabo!
Do you?
Look, this is really none of my    business...
(curious to that     reaction)   You were a witness... I just want to    be sure I get the facts right... for    my... medical report...
I'd really rather you ask somebody    else...
Frankly, I don't understand your    attitude... all I asked was if you    know them well.

Well enough.    (beat, okay, let's     get it over with)   I heard the father was looking for a    new job a couple of months ago and    offered to help them...    (uncomfortable at     telling)   I've visited them on Bajor several    times.
Did you see something that bothered    you?

It has to be torture for that boy...    living like that... hated by people    he considers his parents... told day    after day that he's worthless    Cardassian scum.  Beaten if he even    looks the wrong way.  Rugal's their    revenge -- their revenge against    all Cardassians.
It's not true.  It's not true.  Rugal    will tell you.  We haven't mistreated    him... Is this another Cardassian...
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: There'll be plenty of opportunity to    go over the matter in detail... but    during the investigation, we'd like    Rugal to stay with our schoolteacher,    Mrs. O'Brien... she's expecting him    now.
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: What if I refuse?
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: Then I'll have to call Security and    have them remove him from your    quarters... I don't think either of    us wants that...
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: Why?
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: It'll be all right...
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: I didn't do anything wrong...
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: I know.  I know.  It'll be all right.     I promise.
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: I didn't do anything wrong.
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: Nobody's accusing you of a crime,    Rugal.  You're not being arrested.     My name is Commander Sisko.  I believe    you already know Doctor Bashir...
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: Hello, Rugal.
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: I'm sure this will be straightened    out in a day or two... If you want    to visit with your father tomorrow,    you can.
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: Go on, Rugal.  We'll talk tomorrow.    (puts his arm around     his shoulders to     comfort him, gently)   They won't hurt you.  They're humans.     Not Cardassians.
scene: 21   INT. GUEST QUARTERS - CLOSE ON PROKA

quote: Actually, something good did come    out of this, Garak.  If it hadn't    happened, we never would have    discovered Rugal's situation.  A    bite on the hand is worth saving a    boy's life, wouldn't you say?
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: I suppose it depends on whose hand...       I'm only kidding.
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: Perhaps this might even help Gul    Dukat in his efforts to resolve the    entire war orphan predicament.
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: I beg your pardon... ?
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: Gul Dukat... he called Commander    Sisko right after this happened...    Apparently he was quite concerned    with your well-being... you never    mentioned you were friends...
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: You said Dukat was doing something    about war orphans?
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: He wants to bring them all home from    Bajor...
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: Does he...
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: Am I missing something... ?
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: Doctor, what single trait would you    ascribe to me and my fellow    Cardassians?  Would it not be our    attention to detail?  Do you think    we simply forgot about those poor    little orphans when we left Bajor?     Do you think they just... slipped    our mind... ?  And who, would you    guess, was in charge of the Cardassian    withdrawal from Bajor?
scene: 22   INT. INFIRMARY - SURGERY ROOM - BASHIR AND GARAK

quote: I don't know how to thank you...
Don't thank me so quickly.  It's    possible the boy could be returned    to his adoptive parents.
But surely after the accusation    this... businessman has made...
That's all it is for the moment --    an accusation.
We wouldn't take kindly to the boy    being returned to the Bajorans.     However, I have complete confidence    in your ability to be thorough,    Commander.  If there's anything I    can do...
As a matter of fact, there is: if    it's decided the boy should be    returned to Cardassia, who would we    return him to?  It might help to    find out if he has any relatives    still living...
I was just going to suggest that you    forward a DNA sample to us.  We'll    be happy to run it through our data    banks.
We'll send it to you right away.
Excuse me... Gul Dukat, I have a    question...
It's Doctor... Bashir, isn't it?
Yes.  Isn't it true you were in charge    of the evacuation of Bajor?
Yes, I was...
Then it would have been your    responsibility to see that these    orphans were part of the evacuation.     Yet you chose to leave them behind...    why?
I did not choose to leave them behind,    Doctor.  I was ordered to leave them    behind.
Ordered?  By whom?
The civilian leaders.  They...
Excuse me.  But if I understand the    Cardassian political system, the    civilian leaders have no direct    authority over military officers...
Who's been tutoring you in Cardassian    social studies, Doctor?
Your old friend, Garak.

Well, remind my old friend that the    withdrawal from Bajor was a decision    made by the civilian leaders... one    that I clearly opposed... and, yes,    they were the ones who decided to    leave the orphans behind.  I've    regretted that decision ever since.     Thank you for your concern, Doctor.       Good day, Commander.
He's lying.
Is that an opinion or do you have    some sort of evidence?
I have Garak.
Garak.
He thinks there's more going on here    than we realize.
The Garaks of this world spend their    lives weaving conspiracy theories,    Doctor.
What exactly does he think is going    on?
I'm not sure.  He doesn't really    tell me what he thinks... I sort of    have to... deduce it.
So, you "deduced" that Garak thinks    Dukat is lying about something you're    not sure of... and you proceeded to    interrupt my conversation to confront    him about whatever that might be.
I'm sorry, Commander.  It just seemed    an opportune...
Don't apologize.  It's been the high    point of my day.       Don't do it again.
Why would Garak want to undermine    Gul Dukat?
I'm not sure, but I don't think he    likes Dukat very much.
I'd like to ask Garak about this    myself.  Have him in my office at    twenty-one-hundred-hours.
Yessir.
Hi.
Good idea.
What?
Three settings.  I assume you sent    Molly over to stay with the    Fredericks.
She's asleep.  She and Rugal played    all afternoon.  He wore her out...
You let them play together?
Why not?
The boy almost bit somebody's hand    off...
I was with them all day.  He's not    like that... he's really very    gentle...
"Gentle" was bred out of these    Cardassians a long time ago.
You know, that's a very ugly thing    you just said.
I only said...
I don't need to hear it twice.
Rugal, dinner's ready.
I hope you like it.
Keiko -- darling -- what is this?

I found some Cardassian recipes in    the memory bank of our food    replicator.  It's a stew, made with    Cardassian zabu meat.       I thought Rugal might enjoy a dish    that's popular on his own world.
There's obviously been a
Obviously.
Garak, you know you made it perfectly    clear that Dukat couldn't care less    about those war orphans.
The Doctor and I did discuss the    tragic circumstances of the children.     But I would never suggest that Gul    Dukat...
You did.  You did.       He did.
Doctor.
Doctor Bashir, I apologize if I've    inadvertently put you in an awkward    position...
Sorry to put you to this trouble.
Not at all.
By the way, Garak... how long have    you known Gul Dukat?
I barely know the man at all.
Really.  Somehow, I had the impression    from him that he knew you rather    well.  Called you "amiable," if I    remember.
I'm honored that I was noticed by    such a great leader.
How you could just sit there and lie    with that irritating, pseudo-ignorant    smile of yours...
Doctor, I really am disappointed in    you...
You're disappointed in me... ?!
The things we talk about are for    your ears only.  That you would tell    Commander Sisko anything I might    happen to say in passing about Gul    Dukat... is inappropriate and    unacceptable.
Can't sleep?
Want something to eat?
No.

You can come with me in the morning,    if you like.  I'm running a    maintenance check on conduits in one    of the upper docking pylons.  You    get a terrific view of the station    from up there...
Suit yourself.
What're they going to do with me?
I'm not sure.       You might have something to say about    that, you know.  I mean, you should    be telling Commander Sisko what you    want.
I want to go home.
He'll understand that.  You're a    Cardassian.  They should've taken    you home when they left.
No, I mean home.  To Bajor.
But it must be tough for you, living    on Bajor...
Why?
Being Cardassian.
That's not my fault.  I was born    that way.
That's not what I meant.  There's    nothing wrong with being a    Cardassian...
Yes there is.
Who taught you that?
It's the truth.  Everybody knows it.
How do your parents feel about    Cardassians?
They hate them.
Why do you want to live with someone    who hates you?
They hate other Cardassians.  Not    me.  They've never done anything    wrong to me.
Come on, even I got my fanny whacked    by my Da once in a while.
Not me.  My parents follow the    teachings of the prophets.
What do you think of Cardassians?
Me?       I... can't really say.
Why not?

Because you can't judge a whole race    of people.  You can't hate all    Cardassians or all humans or all    Klingons...       I mean I've met some Cardassians I    didn't like.  And I've met some I    did.  Like you.

(evenly, without     emotion)   Do you know how many Bajorans the    Cardassians murdered during the    occupation?  Over ten million.  We    had a test on it in school.       I wish I weren't Cardassian.
Good Night.
Night.
Come, Doctor.  Get dressed.  We need    to be going.
Going?  Going where?
To Bajor.
I take it this couldn't wait 'til    morning...
Nossir.  I need to use a runabout...
I'm waiting --
(knowing this sounds     funny)   It's Garak, Sir.  He wants to go to    Bajor.
Bajor?  What for?
He won't tell me.
Oh, well, by all means.  Will one    runabout be enough?
Ops to Sisko.
Go ahead.
Commander, there's an urgent    communication for you from Gul Dukat --

I'm sorry to disturb you at such a    late hour, Commander... but thanks    to the DNA gene type you sent us,    we've discovered the boy you're    holding is actually the son of one    of our most prominent politicians:    Kotan Pa'Dar.
When was Pa'Dar on Bajor?
Over eight years ago.  He was the    exarch for a Cardassian settlement    there.  The boy was thought to have    died in a Bajoran terrorist attack.
Has he been told his son is alive?
Of course.  And as you can imagine,    he's overwhelmed with joy.  He's    already on his way to the station to    reclaim him.
It's not that simple.
I don't understand.
The boy wants to go back to Bajor.
To live with those same brutal people?
I can't find any evidence to support    that accusation.  I can't even find    the man who made it in the first    place.
Nevertheless when the boy finds out    his real father is alive, he'll surely    change his mind.  And even if he    doesn't, it will be in the boy's    best interests....
I think we'll just have to see what    happens when Pa'Dar gets here.  Sisko    out.
It couldn't just be a coincidence.     Garak must have heard about Pa'Dar    before he woke me up.  But what could    he be looking for on Bajor?
I guess there's only one way to find    out.
Excuse me... is this the Tozhat    Resettlement Center...
Yes...
I'm Doctor Bashir from the Federation    command at Deep Space Nine.  I'm    trying to find some information about    a Cardassian war orphan who was    apparently placed for adoption here...
Yes, the Bajorans have opened their    hearts to many of the abandoned    children...
The boy's name is Rugal.  The Bajoran    who adopted him is named Proka Migdal.
Yes, exactly what are we trying to    find out about them?
The circumstances surrounding the    young man's adoption.  It took place    about eight years ago.
The Cardassians were still here.     You'll never find anything from back    then.

The Cardassians are quite meticulous    about keeping records, Madame.     They've taught many worlds including    this one how to keep records.  I    find it difficult to believe that    none exist from that time period.     Weren't computer entries made on a    regular basis?
I can't tell you.  I wasn't a    volunteer then.  I was in the    Underground.
Really.  Perhaps we've met before.
Do you mind if we check your computer?
Our computers don't work.  And I    can't get a technician to come out.     We're not exactly a top priority.
Perhaps I can be of service.
You know how to fix computers?
I dabble with isolinear data    subprocessors.  It's... a hobby of    mine.
I continue to underestimate you,    Garak.
No more difficult than sewing on a    button, actually.
Excuse me.
You carry this everywhere, do you?
A simple tailoring tool.  You'd be    surprised how often someone needs a    pair of pants let out... Damn.  It's    not there.
What's not there?
Rugal's name.  The father's name.     None of it.
You were able to find eight-year-old    files that quickly...
It's simply a matter of knowing what    you're looking for, Doctor...
It could be misfiled, or under the    wrong name... or this could even be    the wrong relocation center.
I'm not going to any other district    until I know...
That won't be necessary.  We can    access the files of this entire    province from here and download them    onto a data clip.
That'll be thousands of files.
Tens of thousands, actually.
Excuse me, sir... have you come to    take us back to Cardassia?
I'm afraid not, child.       Come, Doctor...       I believe you'll find your computer    system fully operational, Madame.
(enjoying his work     despite the fact:)   Computer, set up a data bank, cross-   referencing age groups, sex and year    of adopt...
Computer, disregard that request.     And shut down all engines.
I'm sorry if you're upset about the    orphans.  Children without parents    have no status in Cardassian society.     The situation is unfortunate, but...    I don't make the rules.
But you do play the game... don't    you.  And there is a game going on,    right now, as we speak... isn't there.
There are always games, Doctor.

That's the trouble -- I don't have    the slightest clue what this game's    about.  So you're going to tell me    what's going on inside that plain    and simple head of yours, my    Cardassian friend, or we're going to    sit here until we rot!
Tell me, Doctor -- why do you think    the Cardassians left Bajor?
According to Dukat, the decision was    made by your civilian leaders...
Isn't it interesting that one of    Cardassia's most notable civilian    leaders has recently entered this    scenario...
Rugal's father.  You're saying Kotan    Pa'Dar was involved in the decision    to evacuate Bajor... ?
Very good, Doctor.  It appears all    of our little get-togethers haven't    been for nothing...
... Which makes him a political enemy    of Gul Dukat, who lost his job as    Prefect when they withdrew...

Now, seemingly out of nowhere, Dukat    expresses an interest in this orphan    boy who has shown up on the station...    and very soon afterwards, with Gul    Dukat's assistance, we find out that    this orphan boy isn't really an orphan    boy at all, but is in reality Pa'Dar's    long lost son...
Another coincidence... ?
I believe in coincidences.     Coincidences happen every day.  But    I don't trust coincidences.
I am Kotan Pa'Dar.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Miles O'Brien.  Come in...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Where is my son?
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: He's with my wife, Keiko.  They'll
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Your son... Rugal...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: ... At least they didn't change his    name...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: ... When was the last time you saw    him?
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: On Bajor... he'd just had his fourth    birthday...    (beat, deciding he     knows what O'Brien     is going to tell him)   He probably doesn't even remember    me, does he?
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: I think he's spent most of his life    trying to forget you.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: I'm not sure I understand.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: The boy hates everything that he is.     Hates Cardassians.  Hates being a    Cardassian.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Yes, I've heard those stories...    well, I suppose after growing up    among the Bajorans... but now that    I'm back in his life...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: He may not want you back in his life.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: (low anger, hurt,     guilt)   I am his father.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: I know very little about human    culture, Mr. O'Brien.  I don't know    how you view The Family...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: We'd do just about anything to protect    our families.  I have a daughter    myself.  Same age as your son was    when you lost him.  Four.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Then I expect you can imagine how I    feel right now.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: On Cardassia, Family is everything.     We care for our parents and our    children with equal devotion.  In    some households, four generations    eat at the same table.  Family is...    everything.       And I have failed in my    responsibilities to my family.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: But you had no way of knowing he was    alive.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: I should have tried harder.  I should    have looked everywhere.       To abandon my son.  To allow him to    be raised a Bajoran.  I have disgraced    everything a Cardassian believes in.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Hello, Rugal...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Do you remember my face even a little?
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: No.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Would you like to see some pictures    of you when you were a child...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: No.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Rugal, you have to understand...    there was nothing left... of the    house... after the attack... your    mother was dead... you...       I cried for you, Rugal.  I missed    you so much.  I could not even stay    on Bajor.  It was too close to the    happy memories of you.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: It was your own fault.  You deserved    it.  You are Cardassian.  What the    Bajorans did, they had to do...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: I understand why you're saying that    but...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: You can't understand.  You're a    Cardassian butcher!  A butcher.     They killed your son for your    crimes.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: Rugal...
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: You are not my father!  And I will    never go back to Cardassia.  Never.
scene: 44   INT. O'BRIEN'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON THE DOOR

quote: I have no intention of allowing a    Bajoran court to rule on the custody    of my son.
You gave up custody when you abandoned    him here.
He is my natural born child.  As    Cardassian law clearly stipulates...
... there is no more Cardassian law    on Bajor...
(beat, rises to stop     the exchange)   Gentlemen, I think you may need an    arbitrator to settle this.
It would have to be someone who is    neither Bajoran nor Cardassian.
What about you?
(expected this, to     Pa'Dar)   I'd be willing but wouldn't you have    objections... because of the    Federation's relationship with    Bajor... ?
No, Commander... I know you are a    father too.  You would be acceptable    to me.
Very well then... I'll schedule a...
Odo to Commander Sisko.
Yes, Odo.  What is it?
I thought you might be interested to    know... Gul Dukat has just arrived    on the station...
Station log, Stardate 47177.2.  The    arrival of Gul Dukat only powers my    suspicion that we are being    manipulated in some unseen manner.     But how.  And for what purpose?
Doctor Bashir and Garak continue to    search for anything of relevance in    the adoption files.  So far, they've    found nothing.
The decision on custody for Rugal    cannot wait much longer...
You've come a long way just to view    a custody hearing.
Pa'Dar is an eminent member of the    civilian assembly.  This matter has    generated a great deal of interest    at the highest levels of our    government.
So, you're here representing your    government?
Not exactly.       I'd like to think that I'm here    representing the children.  All of    the children abandoned on Bajor.  I    want to see Rugal reunited with his    father.
I'm sure Pa'Dar is grateful for your    support.
Because I was under the impression    that you were political adversaries...    isn't that so, Pa'Dar... ?
We have disagreed in the past, but    Commander, I don't see what you...
And I must object as well, Commander.     What's past is past.  It has no    relevance here.  All that is relevant    is the children.  What are we to do    about the children?
If you don't mind, I'd like you to    go over the events leading to the    disappearance of Rugal eight years    ago...
How perfectly foolish of me.
Don't tell me you've decided you're    wrong... not after scanning seven    thousand, four hundred and twenty    files for a misspelling...
Dukat is smarter than that.
Than what?
He would never leave a file to be    found.
You really think he purged the file    on Rugal?
I would have.
There was something in that file he    didn't want anyone to see.
Exactly.
We have one last chance... if we can    find the person who wrote that file    in the first place...
How can you ever hope to find him?
Her.
Her?  How do you know?
Because I've already found her name.     Jomat Luson.
But how...

Really, Doctor.  You're not paying    attention to detail.  There's one    name we keep seeing... on all of the    files from the Tozhat Resettlement    Center during the time period Rugal    would have been there... a Bajoran    official named Jomat Luson.  Now,    all we have to hope for is that she's    still alive...
Do you remember anything from back    then, Rugal?
No.
Do you remember being adopted?
No.
What's the first thing you do    remember?
My father... teaching me how to    swim.
I know exactly the one you're talking    about.
You do?
He was the only Cardassian boy we    had at the time... we had several    girls...
You're sure his name was Rugal...
That's what we were told...
Somebody told you his name?

Yes, that was the most unusual thing    about his arrival.  Virtually all of    the other Cardassian children turned    in to us were found on the streets    by Bajorans... Rugal was brought in    by a Cardassian.
A Cardassian military officer, by    chance?
Yes, as a matter of fact, she was.
A woman...
I don't remember her name... but she    was attached to the command post at    Terok Nor.
Is there anything else, Doctor?
The boy accused him of being a    butcher.  He just hates Cardassians,    sir.  Pa'Dar was heartbroken.  I    could only imagine how I'd feel in    his shoes.
Commander, may I ask Chief O'Brien a    few questions?
Chief, didn't Pa'Dar tell you about    the humiliation he feels right now?
He said he'd disgraced everything a    Cardassian believes in.
Has the news of your son's discovery    become public knowledge on Cardassia?
The government has not chosen to    reveal it to the people yet.
What happens when it is revealed?
It will be the end of my political    career.
That's a shame.  Especially    considering the timing.
The timing?
Isn't there an inquiry about to begin    concerning the Cardassians who    supported the recent, attempted coup    on Bajor?
Yes.
And isn't Gul Dukat a key witness in    that inquiry...
This is irrelevant and an insult.     You've lost control here, Commander.
(you have my support,     Doctor)   Yes, it seems that I have.  Again.
I suggest we get back to the issue    of the children.
All right, let's talk about children.     Have you ever been to the Tozhat    Resettlement Center on Bajor where    Rugal was adopted?
Never.
And of course Tozhat is the province    where Pa'Dar was stationed eight    years ago.
I'm aware of that.
I've been trying to find the records    of Rugal's adoption but they're    missing from the files.
How unfortunate.
But we have found someone who was    working at the center at the time    Rugal was brought in.  Do you know    of a Bajoran social volunteer named    Jomat Luson?
No.
Jomat Luson remembers Rugal being    brought in by a Cardassian military    officer.  A woman who seemed familiar    with him... even knew his name.
Is there a question?

The question is whether or not this    officer might have deliberately left    the son of Kotan Pa'Dar at the    relocation center... with full    knowledge that he was not an orphan.     Perhaps with the hopes of humiliating    Pa'Dar someday.
I wouldn't know.
Would you happen to know of a base    known during the occupation as Terok    Nor?
Terok Nor?  It was here.  This space    station.
Jomat Luson clearly recalls the    officer who brought in Rugal was    attached to Terok Nor.
Gul Dukat, who was the commander of    Terok Nor eight years ago?
For the record, the commander of    Terok Nor eight years ago was Gul    Dukat.

Station log, Stardate 47178.3.  After    long and difficult deliberations, I    have decided to allow Pa'Dar to take    his son back to Cardassia.  Although    I am convinced his Bajoran foster    parents treated him with love, Rugal    has been the clear victim in this    conspiracy.  I believe it's time for    his healing to begin.
Your doctor has given me the leverage    I need, Commander...
Leverage?
Dukat will never allow these events    to be made public now.  And I    certainly won't choose to discuss    them.
A stalemate.
A stalemate.  You've helped me salvage    my political career.  I won't forget    that.
Perhaps you'll use your influence to    help the other Cardassian orphans on    Bajor.
Yes, well... we'll see.
Remember what I said.  If you ever    want to come back and visit them --    let me know, and I'll arrange it...
Hello, Rugal -- are you ready to go?
I suppose it will take time...
But there's still one more question    I haven't been able to figure out,    Garak... Why did you want to expose    Dukat?  What's the truth about you    and him?

Truth is in the eye of the beholder,    Doctor.  I never tell the truth    because I don't believe there is    such a thing.  That is why I prefer    the simple straight line simplicity    of cutting cloth.
You're not going to tell me.
But you don't need me to tell you,    Doctor... if you'll just notice the    details.  They're scattered like    crumbs all over the table we regularly    share.       Until next time.
